Z5b1oG88.question: You are the pilot of a modern, large turbojet aircraft. In an extended cruise, with the autopilot and all systems operating correctly, what must you do to maintain longitudinal trim of the aeroplane?

options.text: Nothing, the autotrim system will ensure the standing loads on the elevator are removed.
As fuel is used from the wing tips, the CG will be moving forwards, so you must periodically trim nose-up.
Periodically disconnect the autopilot and trim out any standing loads on the elevators.
As fuel is used from the wing roots, the CG will be moving backwards, so you must periodically trim nose-down.

 What must the pilot be particularly careful about in the current situation?

ailerons only.
ailerons and rudder.
all control surfaces in a co-ordinated way.

4. It will depend on the aircraft type but both 1 and 2 can be correct.

options.text: Range within which the stabiliser trim should be set for take-off.

Range within which the stabiliser should be set for landing.
compensates for Mach tuck caused by the rearward movement of the shock wave as an aircraft accelerates.

bDBlYTOf.question: Speed-related protections are fed into a conventional system's control loop, via the trim system, in a predictable and safe manner. Pitch and bank angle limitations...

rely on carefully calibrated electromagnets to apply brakes to control inputs when pitch and bank angle limits are exceeded.
are available in conventional and FBW control systems. These limitations are required data for the computer systems to function but are NOT used to support flight control.
are NOT necessary on conventional control systems. In FBW systems, their sole purpose is to prevent flight control software faults from causing an aircraft to depart from the normal flight envelope.

It blocks the elevator to prevent inadequate trim settings.
